"I don't even know who the fuck you are, and you have no relationship with me of any kind, why would I care what you think I should be doing/feeling" is almost always a helpful little mental reply, for me, anyway

i will say this: if you find you are highly sensitive to being critiqued online, or being told what to do/what to post/how to feel, it may be helpful to take a step back and ask yourself if you even know or have a relationship with the person giving you that feedback

i still haven't quite sorted out in my mind how to productively critique this, and to suggest alternative routes to people -- how do i do this without meta-shaming (shaming people for shaming). the wormhole of it all

but there are a lot of people on this app, and even more on social justice instagram, who seem to think they have a moral imperative to make everyone around them feel as terrified and ashamed as they feel and buddyyy that does not facilitate behavior change or growth
it's a tricky paradox of course because sometimes just sharing your own emotions or perspective as a marginalized person gets you tone policed, and accused of "shaming people," which it's clearly not

i have absolutely zero patience for emotionally manipulative messages on this app at this point. venting is one thing, but telling people what to think, post, or  feel is authoritarian and not gonna achieve the ends you want anyway

often, pp stand up or raise their hand to ask a question at an event because they would like attention in that moment, or they'd like the opportunity to make contact with the speaker directly. understandable human needs but not what a brief q&a portion of an event should cater to

the people most eager & ready to *ask a question* at live events are those most accustomed to being heard. (this is a problem in classrooms too). level the playing field a bit and slow down the process, giving people time to think of questions and the moderator space to vet them.

Whether it's a conference, panel, or even a book release event -- vet your questions! have people submit via a digital ask box or write their questions on note cards. it's so much more respectful of the speaker's boundaries and *everyones* time and creates a far better experience https://t.co/kgK0pS85Bs

but unmasking is a lifelong process of letting go of the self-protective instinct to hide. we're not innately more moral than anyone else. we just struggle with the tension between our values and what society says being a good person "looks like," in unique ways.

Unmasked Autistic people are disliked all the time! we nitpick over fine details others don't want to make time for, we ask questions that aren't "supposed" to be asked, we unpack unspoken assumptions and make them explicit in inconvenient ways, we say no, we refuse to comply
@ccsdevio Thank you for telling me that ! I'm glad it's been helpful

a few years ago, I had to make a major break from some very kind, very fun, very people pleasing friends who had done something cruel I could *not* stand to be complicit in. i had to be willing to make thing awkward. this book helped https://t.co/FEB3aRja5f

but there will probably always be a scared, self-protective part of me that thinks it needs to obscure information people won't want to hear, tell placating lies, mirror people's emotions, and keep the conversation moving along frictionlessly - even when doing so is banally evil

hypervigilance and masking made me dishonest and morally cowardly, tbh. in order to become more candid, and more consistent in my values, i had to become willing to be disliked, learn to remain calm during conflict, and let myself become a hell of a lot more visibly autistic.

the false hope of experiencing this outcome will keep me posting for years https://t.co/JVim6alglL

another benefit of not wasting upwards of an hour per day reading notifications and banal comments is that i'm reading a hell of a lot more essays and books and journal articles these days. including many things i disagree with. depth. delicious mind-cleansing, stimulating depth.

and i'm really more free to explore complex ideas and grow artistically if i'm not terrified of how something will hit for everyone. constantly anticipating aggressive negativity from an unknown mass of thousands is such a suffocating way to try doing anything creative.

I have never done anything  genuinely beneficial to other people when I was terrified of seeming like a bad person. I've never had a clear-headed sense of where my place is, in a larger political struggle, when I was consumed by guilt or shame.

Attempting to manipulate people into feeling negative, avoidance-based emotions like shame, guilt, fear, and existential dread isn't praxis. it's moral sanctimoniousness at its worst, an attempt to create commiseration for yourself at its best/most understandable

Everything we know about human information processing tells us people do not make considered decisions or process information deeply when they are in a state of highly anxious arousal. Fear is a demotivating emotion. Being overloaded or slipping into despair are also demotivating

Often, simply setting out to inform people of the facts of a political situation (a worthy goal! a laudable goal!) is enough to tip people into a state of overwhelm and inhibition. How to educate and empower people instead of debilitating them is a pressing political project.
I just don't think setting out to make people feel guilty, ashamed, or fearful is ever a worthy political goal unto itself.

trust, and directing my attention toward the people worthy of that trust, changes fucking everything. it's such a qualitative difference from the uneasy, on-my-guard, placating way i comported myself before.

if someone is that intolerant of ambiguity, disagreement, discomfort, or tension, they can see themselves out. it's unreasonable and unhealthy for me to think i can manage every little emotional reaction from every reader or rebut every possible negative response

if im so disposable to someone that i can never say something that rubs them even slightly the wrong way, if i have to wrap every perspective i share in a thousand layers of caveats and pre-emptive apologies in order for someone to stick around and reflect on my point, fuck em

If someone is actually invested in me (as a friend) or my ideas (as a reader or fellow writer), they won't just lose all regard for me the second I use a phrase they don't like, an example that doesn't hit for them, or share an opinion they disagree with.

now that i dont read comments or DMs from people I dont know, it is AMAZING how little I now steel myself against the worst possible interpretations of my writing. instead of being hypervigilant against every possible bad-faith read, i feel trust toward readers &  those i respect

Interestingly, a lot of people who write about assertiveness & boundary-setting for a general audience ultimately end up recommending a very Autistic approach. "Just answer the question that was asked." "Don't try to mind read or manage others' feelings" "Be clear and direct"

it takes a fuckton of unlearning, **community support** & self-advocacy skills as an Autistic to finally say "no, you know what, i'm not the one who communicated incorrectly here," cease trying to mind read, & force NTs figure out that they need to say what they mean

I have noticed (and people close to me have observed) that I try to show up for everyone about equally. when my behavior doesn't show discernment between those I am truly close to and randos I just don't want to disappoint, it hurts my relationships, and myself.

& this is me being descriptive more than prescriptive. this is just a thing that people, rightly or wrongly, need to be aware of and realize they are (in the eyes of the law and the app's functionality) rendering possible as an outcome, when they post publicly.

if you are uncomfortable with a post or comment of yours being shared, cited, or quoted anywhere, you shouldn't be making it publicly. Millions of other users cannot & will not take responsibility for enforcing your boundaries on your behalf & the app sure wont either.

These sites are predatory and use our free public content as a means of delivering eyeballs to advertisers. users also can & will take free reign over any public post they encounter, because that's built into legal precedent, social norms & the apps' functionality

Attempting to use the framework of sexual consent as analogous to a person resharing your public content on a public platform is... not appropriate, and thinking of it that way is also just going to, fairly or not, set you up for a lot of frustration and anxiety as a user

It truly brings me no pleasure to see people feeling uneasy with their stuff being shared. I think also people need to be aware for their own safety that when they make a public post on a public platform, it can & will be RT'd, QT'd, screenshot, cited, quoted in print, etc

Multiple times at this point, I've heard people claim that resharing a public comment that they left publicly on a public post is somehow a violation of their consent. I have also seen people claim their consent was violated by having public tweets quoted in books or articles

It truly brings me no pleasure to see people feeling uneasy with their stuff being shared. I think also people need to be aware that when they make a public post on a public platform, it can & will be RT'd, QT'd, screenshot, cited, quoted in print, etc

You can pursue formal diagnosis if you want, for legal protection and educational access. It will never be what makes you Autistic. If you're uncertain whether you are,  meet more of us and join in community with us. We need eachother far more than we need psychiatric approval.

Self diagnosis is not just "valid" -- it is liberatory. When we define our community ourselves and wrest our right to self-definition back from the systems that painted us as abnormal and sick, we are powerful, and free.

A gender identity diagnosis disorder was never what made a person trans. In fact, that diagnostic process shut the majority of trans people out. Requiring diagnosis was counter to trans liberation and acceptance. 

The exact same is true of Autism.

For decades a diagnosis of gender identity disorder was required to "really" be trans.  But outside of that psychiatric gatekeeping system (which claimed absurd things like that gay trans people don't exist) there were thousands & thousands of trans people existing as themselves.
Imagine non-hierarchical, patient- and community- need driven care. https://t.co/9qXmUp75ye

Correct. I don't care one iota whether a person pursues diagnosis or not. I care that we treat a benign source of human diversity like it's a disease, and keep Autistics from finding one another and themselves. https://t.co/GF4JfZfBYg

I think of it this way. If you think your kid might be gay or trans, you gotta help them get to know their community. Diagnosis is often not what Autistic kids need so much as the self knowledge and acceptance that comes with actually Autistic community. https://t.co/SUIIXZzXOM

Either you actually believe Autism, ADHD, and etc are neutral sources of diversity deserving of acceptance in society, or you think they are disorders that must be diagnosed -- but it makes no sense to try and claim both those things simultaneously.
The concept of neurodiversity and the process of psychiatric diagnosis are fundamentally incompatible with one another.

(and i know how fucking pretentious it sounds to say any of this but like... people really are in my DMs and comment sections saying really intense stuff like that all the time. and that kind of intense perceived connection has a darker side, too, and i'm done with it).

When people say that my work (or any piece of creative work) has saved them in some way, I just want to say No, you saved yourself. You willing engaged with something I left behind a long time ago. You generated meaning from it, and put it to use in your own life. You did that.

I'm glad my work means a lot to people. And I will never be able to actually feel that impact. When a piece of writing touches your heart or changes you for the better, that is largely a creative act you are engaging in as the reader. I am not a part of it. I am not there.

One really jarring wake-up call has been watching many of my social media followers act overly familiar and inappropriate to an *actual* friend of mine, @dr_dvonp , and do weird shit like message me criticism about how she lives her life. Like who the fuck are you go awayyyyyyy

Multiple people close to me have noted recently that my personal creep-dar is not strong enough. I give people the benefit of the doubt and approach most conversations way too earnestly and openly. No wonder I get so worn down and jokerfied. I let strangers use me up! enough!!!

Other social media rules I have newly set: 
1. turn on notifications for messages from real friends, turn off all others notifications. Don't read comments, mass delete DM requests. 
2. restrict/block people the second they say anything weird and parasocial

It sucks to be entering this era, because I have used the internet as a social connector for a very long time and life-changing relationships and collaborations have come from that. But I can't do that on a platform where 36,000 random people believe they have access to me.

99% of the DMs I get are rendered immediately irrelevant to me by simply asking that first question -- do I even know who the fuck this person is? If I don't, why do I care what they think? Why would I believe whatever they're claiming or sharing? Also true for comment sections.

I thought quantifying what counts as an "actual" relationship would be difficult -- it's not a matter of online versus irl, bc I have genuine years-long friendships that are online only. But honestly, it's been very easy so far. Do I know this person, like them, and respect them?
Sorting everyone I have an actual relationship with into the "primary" folder, hurling everyone else into the "general" folder and slamming the lid shut on that mf.
Day 3 of not reading any IG DMs from anyone I do not actually know and i already feel like a completely new, purified, mentally clear, more patient person

(if anyone else wants to share ways in which pleasure/turn ons helped inform changes you made to you appearance or otherwise guided you toward gender euphoria, please do! trans or cis ppl!)

some examples to make things more concrete: bottom growth from T is a huge turn on. I feel more at peace and whole because it feels so good. 

Wearing a binder is a turn on! The pressure/containment does something for me. That pleasure is part of why I dont want top surgery.

sometimes, pleasure asserts its message so strongly that even decades of cultural programming and shame cannot silence it. like all your emotions, pleasure is trying to protect and guide you. What would it tell you, if you could listen?

lots of people -- both trans and cis -- make changes to their appearance bc looking a particular way or having a certain body feature turns them on. this is fantastic actually. pleasure is a powerful indicator of what we might do in the absence of the shame that's restricting us.

Your life is for you. Your body is you.  Anything that will make you feel more excited to look in the mirror, or at peace when you're alone in the tub is more than justified by its emotional benefits. and btw -- "this is hot and turns me on" is a valid emotional benefit.

if you believe in body autonomy and gender expansiveness, you should support people's right to do any cute, frivilous, vain, freak shit to their bodies that they think will make their life nicer. that includes cis people. that includes you.

tattoos can be gender affirming procedures. butt lifts can be gender affirming procedures. getting a weird little rat boy haircut can be a gender affirming procedure. nipple piercings can be gender affirming. who gives a shit. if it makes you enjoy being alive more thats huge.

As many before me have noted, we don't require cis ppl to prove that getting a breast augmentation, chin implant, or liposuction for gynecomastia is "lifesaving". They can just go and do it because they think it would look cute and be fun to have. you deserve the same frivolity.

People are fantastic at mounting elaborate defenses around pain they believe they have to get used to. You may think surgery, hormones, dressing differently, electrolysis, whatever sound like luxuries, but if any of those sound pleasurable to you, you deserve that pleasure.

Before I came out as trans, I too would have claimed that I didn't "need" to go on T, or to present differently, because hey, I had survived fine up to that point. I had no idea how miserable I was because I hadn't known relief from that misery since age 12 or so.

A thing I hear from many gender-questioning people is the idea they don't "need" to transition, it's not a life-or-death-matter for them, and so they shouldn't do it. One problem with that logic is just how much human beings can get accustomed to quiet low-grade lifelong misery.

tho we're taught to believe otherwise, our purchases are not the way we change the world. frantic individual action in the name of at least "doing something" often backfires and does more harm than good. sometimes just doing nothing, consuming nothing, is the greater act

psychologists are well aware of the "negative footprint effect": people try to overcome eco-unfriendly actions by buying eco-friendly items like fuel-efficient cars and appliances. but often the resources used to produce new items often cancels out the benefits.

another example of this principle: buying "Green" products such as reusable tote bags. buying new things = waste associated with production. lots of it. even if it's a 'green' item. you'd have to use a tote daily *for 54 years* to justify its production. 

https://t.co/GMJkVX8g6l

Here's the source! Our individualistic, capitalistic culture teaches us the answer to all problems is activity, and lots of it. but often if we just stepped aside and *stopped* actively destroying things, we'd be a lot better off 

https://t.co/iahaXmmFoW

a lot of people who make work the center of their lives are not  doing so because they love it, or because they are hard-driving and goal-oriented in their careers, but because they are profoundly lonely and unfulfilled, with no community, and work fills painfully empty hours

In a lot of ways I've become *more* driven as a person after becoming anti-work. I have actual goals now for what I want my life to look like, how I want to spend and appreciate my time, meaningful things I want to make -- workaholic me filled all those holes with empty labor

What truly separates the workaholic me of the past from the anti-work me of the present is not differences in drive or motivation. The real difference is that workaholic me was a deeply unhappy & lonesome person, but anti-work me has things to live for in the present.

when we take a structural problem and recast it as a unique personal experience of virtuous suffering and martyrdom, it blocks us from joining up w other people to fight for a solution. we come to view humanity as the problem. nobody is worried enough. no one is trying enough.

and it's always individual suffering that is morally prescribed, too -- no matter how collective the root of the suffering is. so we can't all be collectively worried about COVID, for the sake of all people affected by it -- instead we have to be outraged others dont care as much
this political belief is also, ultimately, rooted in the very Puritanical notion that suffering is virtuous, and that even the *absence* of shame and fear can itself be a shameful, immoral state

RT @kim_from_kansas: @drdevonprice I haven’t finished a book since 2015. I’ve been beating by myself up about it for years. Last year I dec…
@kim_from_kansas thank you for adding it -- i think people should just take what they can get out of a book and move on whenever they need to -- i think what you're doing is great advice

books are products, and they're conceived of & sold based on a lot of factors that have nothing to do with what's actually between the covers. if the text of a book doesn't live up to the promise of its cover, or concept, or even its first few chapters, go ahead & let it go

I'm really proud of both of my books, but I also think some people can read the essay version of Laziness Does Not Exist and *get* the concept so deeply that reading the book would be completely unnecessary for them. and that is totally fine

so if you read a bit of a book, and think you Get the Gist, and don't feel like the author is making good use of your time... it's fine to put the book down. I am all for people taking a slow, methodical, in-depth approach to learning, but some books are padded products.

And so a lot of nonfiction books, even ones w really killer, punchy concepts behind them are...padded out with fluff. as a reader, I can *feel* when an author reached the end of their Best ideas and had to start just throwing in tissue paper. you probably can sense it too.

As a nonfiction author you are selling a pitch, an outline, an idea that is catchy and marketable -- and sometimes, honestly, a killer concept does not require 70,000 words to fully execute. some books could have just been really good essays. but thats not how the biz works.

nonfiction authors sell  *proposals*, not completed books. editors buy our projects based on how strong the *idea* of the book sounds, not the reality of it. (plus how marketable we already are, based on our social media, past writing credits, resume, etc)

If you've ever felt bad about starting to read a book and not finishing it , let me tell you, as a twice-published author: a lot of books just are not worth reading all the way thru. a large % of most books is just padding to make it a large enough product to sell. you're fine.

In America we are taught that work brings a person dignity and helps keep you sharp. But as I have aged I have witnessed in real time how our exhausting, repetitive, meaningless jobs dull us, and make it hard for us to learn, challenge our worldviews, meet new people and expand.

But under capitalism, especially in the US, a person is meant to be a highly focused tool of productivity, narrowing their expertise and how they spend their time. Not a polymath or renaissance person or just someone with a lot of friends. There is no profit in any of that.

People need opportunities to grow & feel capable, otherwise their self-efficacy withers. When your mind expands following a new experience or thanks to a new friendship, you feel more alive and ready to take on even more! Without those things we get sicker and sadder

None of this is good for mental health or longevity. We need new experiences and challenges all our lives. It's no wonder so many of us become entrenched in really poorly thought out belief systems or become overly identified with mass media properties. We are cognitively starved

In America, we don't travel. We don't use our vacation days. We barely have any free time. So we learn so little about the world, and meet far fewer people. We don't pursue new languages, instruments, crafts and hobbies. We spend most of our free time passively absorbing media.

Our jobs make our lives very small. Have you ever watched a friend or relative slowly become a lot harder to relate to, as years and years grinding away at their job narrows their focus and exhaustion dims their spark?
Retirement is often "bad" for people in our culture because of the social isolation and lack of novel stimulation that comes with it, but what people miss is, so is work.

I'm proud of the ideas in my book and I hope my work is part of a larger social movement. But. The way it reaches people is also as a product. And ideas only become products if capital thinks it can gain something from selling it.

Anticapitalism is an ideology but it is also a product. Antiwork is a social movement but it's also a branding strategy. Capitalism inhales everything, makes everything into a commodity, a pacifying distraction, a thing you wear rather than the movement of a collective

many days, I feel like the protagonist of the Fifty Million Merits episode of Black Mirror, who starts out railing against the abusive system he is trapped in -- but eventually is hired and put on retainer by that system, because his railing makes great *entertainment*

but at the end of the day, no matter the message of my writing, my book is still a product. sold by a corporation with a litany of complaints from its employees.

there are SO many toothless "anti burnout" books on the market. nearly all of them telling wealthy white people to relax a little bit because it's okay if they aren't productive "every day." fuck that. my work is for people who are never productive. my work is anti productive

you see a handful of books about how the real problem is capitalism & white supremacy -- they do well -- then you get DOZENS of books about how the answer is getting an anti-distraction phone app, buying some self care trinket, taking a nap. bc then you'll be productive tomorrow!

Books about burnout and anti-work are big business. They are products. They sell well bc they speak to our cultural moment. And very easily, they can be used to defang that cultural moment and turn a global problem into a pacifying individual level 'solution.'

Every time I see a new book that renders the anti-work message a little bit more inert and impotent and reformist ("it's okay if you weren't productive *today*! we all have bad days!" "rest is important because it will help you be more creative!") I die a little more inside.

It would be one thing if every Autistic "social failure" were actually caused by abled people being overly sensitive or manipulatively indirect. But it's really not that simple. Missing a social cue or implied meaning does genuinely hurt and confuse people though.

Did you forget to say thank you? Did you deliver that observation in the incorrect tone? Did she say it was toasty  because she wanted you to turn the heater off? Were you lingering too long? Are they mad at you? Are they mad at you? Will you ever even get to find out?

It's very exhausting, scanning your memory of recent interactions in search of a social failing that often is not even there. 

It really puts a distance between yourself and others, because you never trust you are accepted. it inhibits genuine connection in the moment too.

Repeatedly failing to pick up on unspoken cues (and then paying a hefty social price for it) can instill real hypervigilance in you, and train you to constantly second guess your actions and perceptions.

RT @elmcee: Excellent thread. Please read, and remember: moralizing health is a tool of eugenics.

I don't care how annoyed you are at your boomer mom for still going out to TGI Friday's. It doesn't mean the state should get to meter out access to healthcare based on who it presumes to be morally deserving of life.

Either you think your society has an obligation to care for all its people, no matter their health status and choices, and has a responsibility to facilitate and empower healthy choices rather than to admonish and punish, or you think the state gets to decide who should die.

The precedent that non-vax'd people or 'irresponsible' people who catch COVID deserve to suffer is a very dangerous one. It will harm others whose bodies and choices are moralized in other ways. Queer people. Fat people. People with addictions. People with HIV. Mentally ill ppl.

In Illinois, we've had state lawmakers push for the healthcare costs of nonvaccinated people to not be covered by insurance. Across the country we've seen a push for those who make the 'wrong' choices to be allowed to just die. That's the Biden admin's official position.

If you want people to reduce their risk re:COVID, by all means, empower them with knowledge, ask for events to be adjusted to accommodate a variety of risk profiles, and get angry at employers & govt officials who have taken away ppl's choice to stay home.

If at this point in the endemic you still think there are clear-cut behaviors around risk that are morally the "right thing" and others that are clearly & always "wrong," you have been propagandized into thinking some people deserve to die. And that's heinous to me.

When our institutions encourage us to see health status and health behaviors as moralized, and to define certain statuses and choices as unequivocally "right" or "wrong," it's because they want us to find the deaths of some people as completely acceptable.

I will say that getting some of that contact is what's making it possible for me to face the idea of more restrictions without losing it, now. I feel capable of weathering it because I know it has never felt permanent and unyielding for me, and honestly, I need it not to be.
I can't believe I still see people blaming all of this on individuals having the audacity to need human contact and social events to look forward to, after years of isolation.

Individual people being on their best behavior was never gonna fix this. As long as the vaccination rate globally is outpaced by the spread of mutations, as long as our governments continue to fail us, we will continue to have waves and broken curves and new waves.

People who are more at risk of severe complications or with unvaccinated dependents haven't had that latitude, of course. But also, some people who have stuck by intense protocols this entire time don't face the same mental health risks as me. Risk management's an elaborate dance

Instead, I have been able to incur risk in a managed way throughout this pandemic, widening my social sphere and the types of events I'd attend when that seemed warranted, withdrawing or taking more precautions when needed too, bending some rules when my sanity needed it as well.

If I had been holding out this entire time, incurring as little risk as humanly possible hoping for a day when risk was "gone," each additional wave of COVID numbers (and restrictions) would make me increasingly bitter, mistrustful of other people, and hopeless about the future.

Managing public health risk has to be flexible. There is no such thing as zero risk, and most of us lack the willpower and stoicism to choose the least-risky path forever. Our actions & risk management calculations have to slide up and down as the situation does, as our needs do.

The only reason I'm even slightly coping with rising omicron numbers and the threat of additional lockdowns is because I really lived it up this summer and fall, and got to have a lot of rejuvenating experiences feeling connected to other people. And that's harm reduction, too.

But can we really reach the point of radically accepting life, all life, while still under capitalism? Can we ever accept ourselves as unproductive beings that simply exist, when you have to work constantly to be able to eat and have shelter? Not really. Not alone anyway.

If we stop measuring people's worth, we can simply be, and allow others to simply be, too. You don't have to twist your mind around to find some way to justify your value to others. You can reject the question entirely. Earn your right to be alive? you're already alive.

Life just is. There is no need to earn it. As Graeber points out in Debt: The First 5000 Years, we would never ask what debt a tree owes to the forest. The tree is the forest. It simply is. Society is people, just as a forest is trees. We owe nothing to it. We are it.

We can't measure human life that way. In fact, we should not measure it at all. If we simply accept that life is, and let go of the capitalistic urge to justify it or to measure its value, we can finally be free of the fantasy of forever-growth and forever-productivity.

And so, if you measure your life by your productivity, or you evaluate others by what they 'contribute' to the economy, you will always see humanity coming up short. We cannot be productive forever, or even for particularly long.

When you're a child, you can't generate profit for anyone. When you're very old, you can't be productive either. When you're sick, when you're caring for someone, when you're sleeping, when you're healing and growing, you can't be a source of profit. That's most of human life.

An economic system that worships forever growth is one that cannot process loss or tolerate the changes that come with aging. Yet for the vast majority of our lifetimes, we are not capable of being productive at a high level. Our economic system *cannot* value human life.

With time we accumulate new limitations. A lot of masked Autistics are able to produce at a high level in our youth, but the burnout that descends upon us after years of such a grueling performance may not ever go away. some of us never regain that original productive capacity.

We move more slowly as we age. We get hurt and sick more easily. As we grow older we have to tend to the repeated injuries (both physical and mental) that a youth filled with hyper-productivity did to us.

As people get older they have more doctors appointments to manage, and are more likely to have childcare and elder care obligations. Health & mental health issues that we brushed under the rug in our 20s often demand we address them in our 30s and beyond.

As we grow older, we tend to accumulate more responsibilities beyond our work or art, and as we and our loved ones age, we face more emergencies, tragedies, injuries, and illnesses. With age our reaction time goes down. Recovery time from illness and hangovers and injury extends.

Your productivity will go down as you age. No one remains as productive as they were in their 20s and 30s, for lots of reasons. If you're in that age bracket you are probably already functioning at your lifetime maximum. It will go down. How will you get comfortable with that?

See that is exactly *why* I like the word disordered! I want to be someone who upends the prevailing order. I want to be deviant -- considering what being orderly and conforming looks like. Big fan of Mad Pride as a movement and term for that reason too. https://t.co/6r1d4nLq5t

The truth is, many of us with mental disabilities would still face challenges in a world free from capitalism. Many of us would still be disabled. But we'd be disabled in different ways, and think of ourselves and our relationships to others very very differently.

Unfortunately, when you point out the role capitalism plays in defining mental health, a lot of people with diagnoses get offended, because in their minds, their diagnosis is the one thing that has finally given them permission to not meet capitalism's standards.

when I say mental illnesses are diagnosed according to the standards of capitalism, that doesn't mean mental illness doesn't actually exist. It's just that psychiatry defines illness not by whatever challenge it presents to the individual, but how it inconveniences capitalism.

Mental disorder labels are one of the ways that capitalism rationalizes itself and keeps us from questioning the oversized demands it places on individuals. To be mentally healthy, under capitalism, is simply to be capable of meeting capitalism's productivity demands.

A core component of how mental health disorders are assessed is by the degree to which they impair "normal functioning." The more we associate hyper-independence and a high degree of productive output with "normal functioning," the more people have to get branded as disordered.

ADHD is undeniably real. and also, as society places more & more demands on the average person's executive functioning, and the world becomes increasingly stressful & distracting, we'd expect more people to qualify as ADHD or executive functioning disordered as a matter of course

I don't think being closeted and cishet passing is "easier" than being visibly queer (though it comes with certain forms of safety). it is a state of unknowing and alienation. your ID is valid, but only getting to be yourself between your own ears is not good for you.

If you're invisibly trans or queer, or closeted, I would encourage you to get the hell out there and start living your identity, bc it really is life changing. Get on the hormones, fuck some people, make queer friends irl, screw up and get corrected. validity isn't enough.

That doesn't let them off the hook for homophobia, sex negativity, transmisogyny, or entitled obnoxiousness -- behavior is behavior. if someone's behavior is out of line they need an education. But the idea that it's proof they're basically straight/cis privileged? idk abt that.

from the second we are born, queer people are brainwashed to hate ourselves and to not even know that people like us exist. yeah, i know a lot of closeted & baby queers are annoying and microaggressive. that doesnt mean they aren't victims of that deep seated conditioning.

every queer person's first experiences of homophobia and transphobia occur before they are out. we are oppressed the minute someone puts a gender marker on our birth certificate, the moment adults start commenting on our bodies and projecting onto our futures. it is everywhere.
RT @iwritecoolstuff: @drdevonprice and you would think that by now people would realize that both are equally violent in some ways, and tha…

both the suffering that comes from being closeted/invisibly queer *and* the suffering that comes from being visibly queer have the exact same roots: cissexism and heteronormativity. if the world were not ruled by these oppressive forces, we wouldn't even *have* a closet.

it hurts to be clawing at the inside of yourself, unsure of your identity or what you need, your queerness completely unconnected to community and unseen. it sucks to have a target on your back everywhere you go, to never be coherent to medical, educational, governmental systems

but this shit is not quantifiable. every experience of privilege and marginalization is different. we can just speak to how we each individually feel, what we have experienced and what we need, without every description being some symbol or a declaration of status on a hierarchy

Privilege and oppression should not be a competition. I think many people vie online to position themselves as the 'most' victimized by a particular marginalization because they believe that unless they are the most oppressed they will not be heard, or dont deserve to be heard.

But privileges are discrete, specific things, and they don't add up to a coherent understanding of who is "most oppressed" and who is "least oppressed." knowing who i am, not wanting to die, not having an eating disorder, being able to connect to people? those are privileges too.

There is a difference between being visibly trans, or a medically transitioning person, and being someone who doesn't experience those things. If you've never had to steel yourself for a fight with a doctor, insurance provider, or stranger in a restroom, yes thats a privilege

Many people seem to understand oppression in terms of who screams at you while you're walking down the street. But most experiences of oppression are far more quiet and pervasive -- they occur every day in our schools, in comments our families make, in our heads.

Before I understood who I was, and before I had given myself permission to live as myself, I was so held down by cissexism I couldn't even really function as a person. And I was only in that horrible position because of society's forced gendering of people.

At the same time, when I was not out and not visibly trans, there were many aspects of the trans experience I did not understand. And I have met many a non-transitioning enby person who is oblivious to their privilege and blithely speaks over gay cis people, trans women, etc.

I just don't relate to the take that says when you are closeted or not visibly trans you have it easier, because those were the years when I was the most psychologically poisoned by cissexism, and the closest to death. Oppression was working on me whether you could see it or not.

The discourse about the differences between being invisibly trans and not feeling "valid," versus being visibly queer/trans & facing violence day to day... I don't really know what to make of it. I've been both, and both were horrible, in different ways, but with the same roots.

Autism was originally categorized as a form of childhood schizophrenia. There is no separating us from other neurodivergent people. We are the same. The worst things said about other neurodivergent people have all been said about us too.

If you're an Autistic self-advocate but you think people w personality disorders or psychosis are scary, dangerous, or evil, you aren't really a believer in disability justice yet. you aren't invested in neurodivergent liberation. you want social respectability for yourself.

Psychiatrists called us cold blooded & incapable of compassion. They still call ppl w ASPD that. They called us manipulative & emotionally explosive. They still call people with BPD that. They believed we were entirely self-centered and incapable of love. Still say that abt NPD.

look at how psychiatrists have historically spoken about Autistics and you will see the exact same kind of violently dehumanizing ableism that is still routinely directed at people with Schizophrenia, Borderline, Narcissitic, and Antisocial Personality Disorder diagnoses.

Psychiatrists used to speak about Autistics as if we were evil and inhuman. Ivar Lovaas said we were in the shape of a person, but lacked personhood and warmth. How any Autistic person can believe similar claims about ppl with other disorders, like NPD, is beyond me.

Workers have the upper hand in nearly every industry, and it's time we recognize it and leverage it. Say no. Apply to new jobs. Speak openly about how much you get paid. Talk to your coworkers about your grievances. We can make the most of this moment, but we gotta do it together

If you came of age during the great recession, as I did, you have been trained to be agreeable, maybe even downright desperate for work, always logging more hours and taking on more duties without complaint. The time to complain is now. The time to slow down and be a pain is here

I know people who have outright refused to return to the office, causing their bosses buckle under the pressure and keep a position remote. I know people who have threatened to quit and be met with flex time, reduced duties, raises. workers have way more power than they know rn.

I keep seeing workers flexing their power and getting results out of it.  it's unlike anything else in my lifetime. ive seen new hires negotiate to have their commutes be paid for on the clock. ive seen people quit jobs and get better positions three, four days later.

I'm in my 30s, which means I have never been a working adult in a period where the workers had the power, or were even in great demand before. So I know firsthand there is a lot of unlearning to do -- the rules I thought I had to follow no longer apply.

If you believe you don't have the ability to say no at work, speak out about problems, or  up and quit a bad job... it's worth examining whether that belief (which no doubt is rooted in real experience) is still accurate, in the current economic context we're in

there is no class of evil abusive person. there is no innately innocent, safe kind of person. there is only behavior, and motivations that help us make sense of that behavior. abusive behavior is equally wrong no matter who does it, and any type of person is capable of it.

And the frustrating thing is that when Autistics act like we are somehow more pure and innocent and sensitive than people with ~evil, scary~ stigmatized disorders, it means we are less likely to recognize when we hurt someone or recognize the power we have.

But the second you start talking about how the behavior of ppl w Borderline or NPD makes sense under a context of neglect & attachment trauma, you get accused of being an abuse apologist. people really think having those disorders is synonymous with being evil. it's so ableist.

like no wonder someone who's never experienced secure attachment, doesn't know how to connect with people, and has been told all their life that they're broken has an unstable sense of self and volatile behavior. if we can sympathize w that in an Autistic person we can w an NPDer

A lot of the behavioral/relational patterns we call Borderline or Narcissistic make a lot of sense in a neurodivergent person who has no idea how to form healthy bonds yet, because they've been neglected and ostracized all their life. it's not having a "disordered personality"

I could have gotten a Borderline diagnosis in my early 20's SO EASILY. All it would have taken was a single friend or romantic partner sharing with a professional anything I had said or done during a meltdown or any weird impulsive shit I did. And they would not have been wrong!

So many Autistic people talk about having been misdiagnosed as Narcissistic or Borderline, yet our community has SO LITTLE compassion for people w those highly stigmatizing labels stuck on them. It's respectability politics and it's bullshit. There is no difference between us.

My advisor asked me what he had done "wrong" to make me not want to apply to TT jobs. The implication was clear, it was like a parent asking what they had done to screw me up. He had no understanding of any other options. So no. my career path is not diversity. it is deviance.

"Alt academic" has a spirit of rebellion to it, which is appropriate. I had to chose to break away from the one true path that I was supposed to desire. I was pressured to apply to 100s of jobs all across the country and I said, "No <3 i would like to be alive <3"

@ShockleyEllie When I see people in positions of power trying to put a cute rebrand on a systemic inequality, i get crankyyyyyyyyy

But as long as academia functions as a pyramid scheme, with a growing body of credentialed individuals vying for an ever-dwindling number of TT seats, no, we can't call the other places we wind up a lovely positive diversity of outcomes. rather its a paucity of preparation

In a world where a wide variety of professional outcomes and skillsets were imparted to graduate students, with no prioritizing academic TT jobs as the ideal, maybe we could call the wide variety of positions we occupy a source of diversity.

I don't think we need a euphemism that elides the fact that the vast majority of academics are given no training on career paths that are not tenure track jobs. Most of us are forced to invent our own alternatives. It's not "diversity," it's a lack of adequate training.

Do a shitty job. Call it a day when you can tell you're pushing yourself thru the fatigue and listlessness -- those feelings are information, your body and brain are trying to tell you something. And if you care about a task, do a shitty little job consistently, and youll be fine

it's always better to do my shitty little hour or two and then leave it. and let my brain incubate on the project in the background while i'm having a life, the rest of the day. and thats true with like literally anything ive ever tried to get good at. but so hard to internalize

I find myself having to rediscover this over and over again. Any time I'm working on a book proposal I'm amped about, I think I *have* to spend all day every day on it, to force it into existence -fast-. But after an hour or two of work per day, not much of value happens

there's nothing wrong with showing up to your creative practice, banging out a few shitty little words for half an hour, then calling it a night. It adds up. good shit will come out. You'll get practice. And because you aren't *suffering* for hours, you wont hate making art.

Hard work is so moralized that many people actively feel bad for working smart rather than hard. If you find something you can streamline, or a task you can half-ass or forget about because nobody is going to notice it didnt get done, that's canny! Thats smart! It's not shameful.

Many of my students, especially adult learners who have been shamed for being 'lazy' or 'not good at school' in the past, cannot believe that it is okay to cut corners, skim readings, focus on the highest-point assignments, and call it a night early. but its way more sustainable

Instead, I tell my students to be strategic. What's on the study guide? What assignments are for the most points? What concepts are they "muddiest" on? Here's how to actively read. Here's the essential slides, and here's what you can skip (usually the text book).

If you think you need to study for five hours per night (and some profs love providing numbers like that), you're going to make yourself sick with stress and exhaustion, staring at a book all evening, learning almost nothing and feeling lazy or dumb the whole time

Every semester I encounter at least one student who is panicked because they are trying *so hard* and studying for *so long* every single night, yet they aren't groking the material! They feel awful because they think they aren't trying hard enough. I tell them to study *less*

When I first started strength training I overtrained so badly I got almost no gains at all, because I thought I needed to *suffer* every workout. That's really not sustainable. I've gotten so much more out of doing my shitty blase little half hour every other day

Paul Silvia's book How to Write a Lot cites a lot of research showing that asking writers to spend a short period writing every day results in far more creative work, of far higher quality, than asking writers to work in long "binge' sessions. and that applies to so many things

Whether it's making art, exercise, developing a skill, or learning a new subject, consistency matters so much more than intensity. It's so much better to show up and do a shitty little 20 minutes of effort regularly, yet people always *think* they need to work in intense binges

when you live in the "real world" you learn that all rules and deadlines are flexible and fuzzy and that nobody is actually living up to rigid the ideals your teachers told you about.  *communication* about where you are at and what you need matters far more than perfection

and w the population I teach -- adult learners who have work/childcare/eldercare among other things -- what they need is grace, flexibility, and someone willing to answer  questions. "the real world has deadlines" my ass. my students live in the "real world" already.

I think having due dates is helpful for scaffolding and providing students an expectation of where they should be by when in the semester, but if someone slips outside of the lines, the goal should be helping them get back on track, not penalizing them for it.

I don't know what happened in these people's lives that made them fall behind, and frankly, I don't need to. They learned how to clean and prep datasets, import them, run analyes, create linear regressions and time series charts, etc -- just like all the other students

And we are talking about students learning statistics, data visualization, and dynamic programming languages. I spent all of today looking through the charts, output, and code these students wrote. They all did a great job. They kinda nailed it actually.

My Fall 1 classes just ended. I still have no late penalties in place. And you know what? three different students of mine who were *failing* the class a week ago got a passing grade today. they all made up weeks worth of material this week. because I had no late penalties.

When COVID hit, I elected to get rid of all late penalties in my classes entirely. I always was flexible if students requested extensions in advance, but I decided that given ~these times~, flexibility and keeping open lines of communication mattered far more than firm deadlines

In the professional world, it's the norm to update deadlines as needed, revise plans, and communicate when plans have changed so others can adjust. Why not make our classes reflect this? https://t.co/6jdUjUd6xM

@Idzie Yeah, it also baffles me when people ask if it is "okay" to share a public post of mine that is clearly designed to be shared a lot. Idk. I think people have a really distorted or underdeveloped thought process on the whole thing.

I also know *two* different people who were fired from their jobs for sharing anti-capitalist tweets of mine. It's horrific -- but it's good to know that this shit does happen. Block your bosses and coworkers on your socials, go private, do what you need to protect yourself.

These platforms are all terrible and do not care about you, and it's important to know what the risks of posting are, and to make decisions for yourself about how you wish to manage that risk, and what kinds of risks you are comfortable with.

It seems to me a garbled understanding of what consent entails has blended with a lack of knowledge about how privacy and intellectual property rights work on the internet, and left a lot of people with a distorted sense of what the consequences of posting are or can be
I even had someone on Instagram tell me recently that me reposting a *public* comment they had left on one of *my* posts was a violation of *their* consent.

If someone quoting your posts (whether it's in a buzzfeed listicle, an academic journal article, or a nonfiction book) makes you uncomfortable, you probably should not be making public posts on this or any other platform, there's no way to protect yourself from it happening

You are providing free content to these platforms, which allows the platforms to generate advertising revenue. It's information you have provided publicly that others can and will quote, reshare, screencap, etc.

Multiple times this year, I've seen people claim that quoting their public social media posts (whether in a book or on another social media post) is in some way a violation of their consent or their intellectual property rights. People need to understand this is not the case.

we need systemic change, desperately, but we are very far off from even convincing most people that we need systemic change. that is the first step. having these conversations. getting people to ponder the alternatives. the questions about how? those are the answers, in a way.

same thing with abolition. if the mere idea of abolition is so terrifying to you you shut down, because ~what about the rapists~, you need to remember how unpopular it still is to tell white people not to call the cops the moment they feel uncomfortable. we have work to do

in Illinois, a majority of voters went against their best interest last year, &  voted against a progressive tax rate that would have helped them immensely. like, you don't need to worry about a sudden violent communist revolution that hasn't been thought thru, bud.

i realize now that we are so, so far from getting enough people on board with dismantling capitalism or the police state that it's really missing the point to be terrified of what would happen if we got those outcomes right this instant. like, we are in the talking stage lol

i understand why people want a satisfactory, perfect answer. i do. i used to be that person who was like how will we have the 'revolution' in a way that wont hurt disabled people, what will we do about stalkers if there are no jails, etc. i really misunderstood how all this works

@robindarlingg suffice to say, I think there is a way to both talk about the big picture and give people concrete things to do -- but people also need to understand a lot of those concrete steps are things like, idk, talking with one friend for a long time

@robindarlingg i agree, but there is also this desire to offer up quick actionable steps that helps people resolve their anxieties, and it often gets fed into a really reformist or performative lens, and then people obsess over, say, Blackout squares rather than abolition

put the individualistic, white supremacist culture obsession with finding one step that will provide fast perfect results aside. this stuff is centuries in the making. your role in undoing it will be small and the work won't end while you're alive and that is normal

it's fine to ask questions about  short- and long-term strategy, tactics, concerns about who might get overlooked, etc. but it's very absurd we hold the people demanding change to a far higher standard than we have ever held our actual systems, which are cobbled together messes

the systems we occupy were shaped slowly over the course of centuries by a variety of incentive structures, ideologies, social forces, prejudices, and global political developments. if you think we need a flawless roadmap for change to happen, you don't understand history

any time you critique an oppressive system, people come to you demanding a perfectly articulated step-by-step plan for creating a flawless alternative system, today. as if the system we are currently locked inside of were meticulously designed from the top down. it wasn't.

RT @Iolachristina: “It was all toxic femininity,” @drdevonprice writes. “It was a cultural disease. It was nobody’s fault. And everyone aro…

And if "toxic masculinity" is originated in the culture, not in individual toxic or insecure men, then it follows that it is worthwhile to talk about our culture's toxic ideas of what constitutes femininity, or who needs to be feminine, too.

the person who made the post im referencing is trans btw! i have heard multiple trans ppl including some parents make this point before. its like soft transmedicalism logic

despite all stigma and pressure and erasure and violence and coercion to the contrary, some people wind up refusing to be cis anyway. but if we didn't force children at birth to be cis, none of them would be. the idea of children being naturally cis is nonsensical.

but the idea that trying to raise a kid as free from coercive gendering as possible is a damaging thing?? come on dude

so idk, i think assigning children a gender at birth is an awful act that hurts all children, including the ones who "end up" (read: were made to be) cis. but i also understand that for an individual parent trying to resist this stuff its overwhelming

and oh my god i dont envy any parent who is trying to do it. the apparatus of gender assignment being what it is and institutions being what they are, you can't actually raise your kid flawlessly gender free. plus you still have implicit cissexism in your brain as a parent.

now admittedly a lot of the people (esp the cis ones) who profess to be raising their kids free of gender aren't actually doing that by a long shot(just like a lot of "gender neutral parenting" in the 90s wasn't much more than painting the nursery a neutral color).

and i just see it in so many fields. the people who really buy into the narrative of what it means to succeed get so ground up by the system, and over time you can kinda watch their thinking get more conventional and small, and their world becoming so small too.

Maybe if I had worked 80 hour weeks, analyzed data late at night, skipped holidays, half-assed my classes, obsessed over revisions, & never took time to write things I actually enjoyed, I could have become a tenured professor. god i'd be such a ghost of my real self if i did that

No matter what field you're in, most people aren't going to make it to the top of the professional pyramid. Competing for a limited number of prized spots renders us all very easy to exploit. You know how much happier I was when I gave up on being a tenured professor?

If you're the kind of person who really feels a need to stay busy (and I absolutely am one), I really recommend you find ways to scratch that itch that are frivilous, creative, artistic, expressive, collaborative, communicative, and dont produce value for any companies

Every time you decide to expand into a new market, to produce a new product, to consume resources in new ways, to conquer more, to own more -- your productivity is in a very real way a destructive force. People who do nothing rarely hurt anyone, contrary to the cliche.

There is no virtue in keeping busy just for the sake of busyness, of aspiring to more and larger just because you're insecure about your innate worth. So many humans have committed unnecessary acts of destruction, waste, and violence simply in the name of doing "something."

Forever growth is impossible economically, and it's impossible in one's own life. There's nothing wrong with lacking ambition. In fact, finding contentment and letting go of the cultural mandate to forever do more, consume more, produce more, claim more is good for the earth.

Many people tell me they can’t homeschoo…

*and also* service industry workers have more power than they've had in decades. the dynamic is different from what ppl have been conditioned into accepting. you have wayyy less privilege than an office worker like me. you also have more power now than you're used to.

so when i say all of this stuff, i don't want to downplay or deny how much easier it is for a WFH office worker to set limits and screw around at work than it is for a server at a busy restaurant. like. undeniable. night and day.

you know your situation best - you're the expert on how to navigate the prejudices you experience, what you can get away with at work, which coworkers you can trust, & what you need to be sneaky about. this shit isn't easy. you're not crazy. the injustices youve noticed are real.

privilege is a kind of status you are given (or not given) by a structure of oppression. power, in contrast, is something you actively develop & build up, alongside other people, in order to break free of the structure of oppression. don't aspire to privilege. know your power.

"Only the privileged can [take breaks/say no to extra work duties/leave work on time/etc]" is a nasty bit of social programming. it frames basic humane treatment as a luxury that, if you're marginalized, you'll never get to have. but power... is a lot better than privilege.

Exploitative workplaces rely on people believing that they have zero power -- when if every employee actually decided to walk out on time every day, and not be coerced into staying late grinding away, well, the tide would have to change pretty damn quickly. Especially right now.

Right now, the job market being what it is, workers have a LOT MORE LATITUDE than usual to push the limits. Leave on time. Leave early. Say you can't take on two people's jobs. Ask why being given new duties doesn't come with a pay boost. Talk to your colleagues.

Employers really rely on workers being too afraid to ever draw a boundary, for fear of being seeing as noncompliant, disagreeable, not a virtuous enough worker. If we never push the limits, if we are terrified of finding the limits, we'll never know what we can get away with.

It's tricky, because it's undeniably true that the more social status & wealth you have, the easier it is to say no. But it's also a longstanding tool of oppression to convince the marginalized that they must work harder than white, straight, cis people who come from wealth.

Let's talk about the idea that doing less work and saying "no"  is something only the privileged are able to do. Because I think that belief, though rooted in real experiences and dynamics of oppression, is also itself a tool of furthering oppression.

So when people tell me they can't help but be wary of men, because it's an objective statistical fact men are more dangerous -- I wish they'd realize no statistics are objective, and our stats on these things ignore a lot of other dangerous systems of abused power, beyond gender.

But when a white woman is attacked by a man she does not know, particularly a man of color? That statistically really rare event serves the interests of the police state. They document it, broadcast it, use it to justify more funding, weapons, arrests, more murder of Black people

When a white woman sexually harasses a Black male employee, the cops don't record that as a crime and almost no one groks it as violence. When a woman abuses her child emotionally for decades, the crime stats don't budge a bit. the police state is indifferent to it.

Crime stats are not an objective measure of how safe or unsafe a category of people are, and it's strange how many otherwise leftie people will point to them to argue how "dangerous" men are. When you are measuring, as MC Hammer says, you must include the measurer.

Women tend to abuse power differently, because the way their power looks and operates is different. They abuse their children, their employees, queer people and men who are marginalized in ways they are not. The cops don't turn those things into scary racist crime stats.

Much of the abuse women (particularly white cis women) enact on others is not documented by the police state so people behave as if it does not exist and as if women are safer to be around. We always focus on stranger danger,  never on private familial or emotional abuse.

I wish more people understood that the way the police state conceptualizes what counts as "violence" or a "crime" is a huge part of why we get the idea that men are dangerous and scary and that women are pure. And how racist and transmisogynistic the whole framework is.

in the arts, nonprofit sector, and academia, we are taught that it is gauche to care about the money. it means you are unserious about doing the work for its own sake. but who the hell can afford to do any work or art purely for its own sake? who benefits from that ideology?

and any industry that does not generously pay the people who participate in it is, by definition, an industry that is exclusionary to poor people, people of color, trans people, and disabled people. this is true of arts organizations, nonprofits, academia, and academic publishing

so many liberal academics complain about how scientifically illiterate the public is, yet they only ever publish their scientific work behind massive paywalls, and written in the most turgid, jargon-filled inaccessible prose possible.

Shouldn't science benefit the public interest though? How can it if no one can access it? It's not about the sales numbers, it's about whether the info is even accessible to the public. the pricing of journal articles and academic books excludes people from valuable knowledge. https://t.co/kmqYgGGmx3

and this exploitative system means we are robbed of a lot of great scientists and scholars. the ppl who can afford to toil away on a journal article for years for no compensation are super wealthy, privileged people who are unaffected by any structural issues they may write about

Academic publishing truly is a scam. You dont get paid to do the research or write it up. you dont get paid to edit or review. you put years of work into a piece the publisher sells to institutions for thousands of dollars, and you never see a cent. and nobody reads it.

It's impossible for me to feel motivated to write journal articles or academic book chapters that cost thousands of dollars for readers to access, for which I am not paid, when I could write something mainstream that thousands more people see and i get compensated for

Mainstream publishing has MANY ISSUES (please check out #PublishingPaidMe ) but I wish academics would at least take it seriously as a means of getting your work out to the public in an accessible and affordable way, and make money while doing so

I got paid a living wage to write a book with a mainstream publisher, which has been read by thousands of people, and costs under $30 in stores... meanwhile I know academics who got paid zero dollars to write books that cost $200 a copy and never get read.

this isn't to say i dont need help making cuts. GOOD LORD i do. but a great editor helps me cut in a way that opens up the work and helps it say more. and a less great editor cuts away anything challenging

Every bad experience I've had w an editor has involved them "fixing" something that wasn't broken, bc it didn't line up with their assumptions. things like making a bi character straight, or de-capitalizing Autism, or cutting things they assumed readers would find "confusing"
Every great experience I've had with an editor has involved them asking me to open things up, take in more information, and explore something further that I had overlooked or taken for granted.
Working with a great editor makes your work more expansive. Working with a not so great editor makes your work smaller and more limited. in my experience

@BillyFlood20 as a cognitive psych professor once told me -- hate and love are both approach-motivated emotions. dislike, in contrast, is more of a passive avoidance based emotion. always stayed with me.

@PersonalGenius what does "healthy" and "can" mean here
Reading a Single Bad Piece of Science Reporting About How Hot Dogs Will Kill You Takes 35 Years Off My Life

eat whatever nourishes you or brings you pleasure (or helps keep you alive when you can't afford the food you'd really like to be eating). don't read any study that purports to quantify how good or bad an individual consumption habit is. it is less than useless

instead, we take our prejudices, formulate questions designed to affirm them, and then assign a sciency-sounding number to our preconceived notions and call that science. im such a doomer about it because i have seen how this (forgive me) sausage gets made.

and if we were remotely objective and data-based we would be doing you know, thousands more studies on the effects food desserts, poverty, and lack of competent healthcare coverage have on health than on how naughty it is for an individual to eat or drink a "bad" thing

science is never really objective or neutral, because it's human beings with beliefs and biases who set out to study inane, fatphobic shit like "oh huh i wonder how many Bad Anti Life Points we can assign to a single dorito chip"

i really wish more scientists made it our job to call this kind of shit out and hold reporters (and researchers churning out this drivel) to account. it matters so much more than the weird politics and pissing contests we act out in peer review cycles at during conference q&as
RT @kokumkohla: Claims like this I like to call "lickbait"

and of course this is all ideologically motivated by fatphobia, classism, racism -- a desire to pit the blame for wide-scale health disparities on individuals committing the crime of eating a cheap protein source to you know, stay alive.

some things actually can't be known or precisely quantified or predicted at a granular individual level, and it's actually less scientific to act  certain or assign things a serious-looking number value than it is to just say hey, we don't know, who knows what will happen

this rant inspired by Twitter Trending news that tries to math out how much shorter your life gets when you eat a hot dog. they're really out here claiming a competitive eater shortened her life by a documentable number of months because she hate X number of encased meats. right.

individual consumption, individual consumption! everywhere you turn people are obessed with assigning numeric & moral value to individual consumption! drinking a cup of coffee won't have an effect on your heart health that you'll ever know. an oreo doesn't shorten your life
also most bodies are great at purging toxins and repairing damage so moderate doses of even truly "unhealthy" things frequently don't have a lasting effect at all.

You don't, as an individual person, have a measurable lifespan because you haven't died yet. You don't have a health bar floating over your head that depletes a measurable amount when you eat a hot dog or smoke a cigarette. that is not how anything works.

Like, honestly screw the incredibly fatphobic, sensationalistic researchers who even sought out to individualize such a aggregate relationship between variables in the first place, and fuck the reporters who lap that shit up for clicks. so irresponsible and innumeracy spreading

it's such irresponsible science (and statistics) to make claims like "eating a single mcrib takes 2 years off your life" and it really distresses me how many people take such claims completely literally
